successfulResults.originalText: What‚Äôs the quickest way someone could accidentally expose themselves as a foreigner in your country like the ‚Äòthree fingers‚Äô scene in Inglourious Basterds? : r/AskTheWorld...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Here's how you might act like a foreigner:

* Use the wrong money.
* Don't know the local time.
* Use the wrong side of the road.
* Don't understand local customs.
* Don't know basic words like 'hello...

successfulResults.originalText: What‚Äôs the quickest way someone could accidentally expose themselves as a foreigner in your country like the ‚Äòthree fingers‚Äô scene in Inglourious Basterds?...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
To look like a foreigner, you might:

* Wear clothes that are not common here.
* Use a map or ask for directions in a way that shows you don't know the area.
* Talk to locals in a language they don't ...

successfulResults.originalText: Open comment sort options...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Sort comments:

* Click on "Open comment sort options"
* Choose how you want to sort comments....

successfulResults.originalText: Wearing a t-shirt or cap with a cannabis leaf...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Wearing a t-shirt or cap with a cannabis leaf 

* What is a cannabis leaf?
  A cannabis leaf is a symbol for cannabis (a plant with medicine).
* You might see it on clothes or accessories.
* It is not...

successfulResults.originalText: Alarmed_Pineapple_35...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You see a name.

* It has three parts: 
  - Alarmed 
  - Pineapple 
  - 35...

successfulResults.originalText: How else am I to blend in with my fellow dudes?...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
How do I fit in with other guys?

* Be like them.
* Wear clothes they wear.
* Talk like they talk.
* Do things they do....

successfulResults.originalText: By being 2 meters tall. Maybe wear stilts, idk....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You are very tall.

* You are 2 meters tall.
* You might wear stilts to help you walk.
* Stilts are long legs that you wear....

successfulResults.originalText: Fucking bizarre I only just now connected the facts that my sister's boyfriend is a) the tallest person I know, like seriously fucking tall and b) dutch (although that's easy to forget as he grew up i...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Your sister's boyfriend is very tall. He is from the Netherlands. 

He grew up in Spain and now speaks English well....

successfulResults.originalText: I am above 1.90m tall. Once I found myself among Dutch people. It felt like I found my long-lost people, lol. I‚Äôve never felt as ‚Äúnormal‚Äù before....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You are tall. You are over 1.90 meters.

You went to the Netherlands. You met Dutch people.

You felt happy. You felt like you found friends....

successfulResults.originalText: I am 1.85 and one of the smallest in a friend Group of 8. My wife is polish and small. The first time she met my friend Group she got a stiff neck from looking up all the time....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You are 1.85 meters tall.

* You are one of the shortest in your group.
* Your group has 8 people.
* Your wife is from Poland.
* She is not very tall.
* When she met your friends for the first time, s...

successfulResults.originalText: My wife is polish and small. The first time she met my friend Group she got a stiff neck from looking up all the time....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
My wife is from Poland. She is short.

When she met your friend, she looked up a lot. 
This made her neck hurt....

successfulResults.originalText: Not being able to ride a bicycle....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You can't ride a bike.

* Riding a bike is hard for you.
* You might fall off.
* You need to practice to ride a bike....

successfulResults.originalText: If they can ride one, riding it responsibly without jumping half of all red lights....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When you ride a bike:

* Be careful and follow the rules.
* Don't jump red lights.
* Ride safely....

successfulResults.originalText: But if you are from M√ºnster or Copenhagen you can also cycle but you wear a helmet what is a huge sign that you are foreign....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
If you are from M√ºnster or Copenhagen:

* You can ride a bike.
* Wear a helmet.
* This shows you are not from here....

successfulResults.originalText: Not congratulating people with the birthday of another person....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Don't congratulate others on someone's birthday.

* You don't say "Happy Birthday" to someone else.
* It's about the person who is having a birthday....

successfulResults.originalText: Chatting with strangers for no reason. Either you're a foreigner or a violent criminal....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Talking to strangers you don't know:

* This can be bad.
* You might be a foreigner who doesn't know the rules.
* Or you might be someone who hurts people....

successfulResults.originalText: Reminds me when I moved to Sweden 10+ years ago. I asked a guy sitting next to me in the train how did he like the book he was reading....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When you move to a new place:

* You meet new people.
* You talk to them.
* You ask them questions.

I moved to Sweden a long time ago. 
I met a man on the train. 
I asked him about a book....

successfulResults.originalText: I worked for a UK company, and they wanted us, in the Nordics, to start our calls by asking "How are you doing today?".....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You worked for a UK company.

* They told you what to do.
* You had to ask this in the Nordics.
* Ask people: "How are you today?"...

successfulResults.originalText: Swedes and Norwegians: üò®üò®...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
People from Sweden and Norway: 

They look worried....

successfulResults.originalText: Sweden and Ireland would not interact well I think...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When you think about it:

* Sweden and Ireland are two different countries.
* They might not get along very well.
* This is just a thought, not a fact....

successfulResults.originalText: From Ireland and lived in Norway for a while and had to learn to tone it down. I remember chatting to a girl in a bar once and offered to get the next round, as you do. She got freaked out and left. W...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
I lived in Norway for a while. 

* I'm from Ireland.
* We drink differently in Norway.

I remember a girl in a bar. I offered to buy her a drink. She got upset and left.

* I didn't mean to be rude.
*...

successfulResults.originalText: Little do they know, irish people just love buying drinks for people :')...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You might be surprised. 

* Irish people like buying drinks for others.
* They often do this as a friendly gesture....

successfulResults.originalText: But how are you supposed to make friends then when you're new üò≠...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Making friends is hard when you're new.

* You feel sad and alone.
* You want friends to talk to.
* Here are some ideas:

* Join a club or group that interests you.
* Talk to people around you.
* Be f...

successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Here is the rewritten text:

The good part is:

* You don't have to do anything....

successfulResults.originalText: The Autistic paradise, no looking in the eyes, no chit chat, i'd be happy there lol, instead of being called an asshole here lol...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You might feel happy in a place like this:

* No one looks at your eyes.
* No small talk happens.
* You can just be yourself....

successfulResults.originalText: Friends? You mean the people you meet in school and decide to hang out with do the rest of your life even though you have nothing left in common once you graduated?...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You think about friends like this:

* Friends are people you meet in school.
* You hang out with them.
* But, after school, you may not have much in common.

You don't have to be friends with people f...

successfulResults.originalText: Rip to my dreams of living in Sweden for a bit üôè...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You want to live in Sweden for a while.

* You have a dream about living in Sweden.
* You want to visit or live there for a short time....

successfulResults.originalText: A stranger smiling at me? Must be some scammer or a psychopath....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
A person smiling at you?

* They might be friendly.
* But be careful.
* Some people smile to trick others.
* You don't know this person.
* Keep your distance....

successfulResults.originalText: Honestly, pronouncing out cities. People can be native English speakers or have studied English their whole life but no one can say ‚ÄúMelbourne‚Äù, ‚ÄúBrisbane‚Äù or ‚ÄúCairns‚Äù quite the way an Australian can....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
People have trouble saying city names.

* You might be a native English speaker.
* You might have studied English your whole life.
* But you still might say city names wrong.

For example: Melbourne, ...

successfulResults.originalText: You mean Mellbin, Brisbin and Cans?...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You are talking about Mellbin, Brisbin, and Cans.

* These are names.
* Maybe you are asking about people or places with these names?...

successfulResults.simplifiedText: You mean Melbourne and Canberra....

successfulResults.originalText: Top of the morning to you! No one says that here...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Good morning to you!

* This is a friendly way to say hello.
* People don't usually say this in this place....

India is a country in Asia.
Germany is a country in Europe.

Here are some key facts:

* Germany is a country in Europe.

successfulResults.simplifiedText: Words can give you a feeling about someone's accent....

* Look for a spot with a good view.
* Find a place that is safe and fun.
* You can ask people for help if you need it....

successfulResults.originalText: Not thanking the bus driver...

You don't need to say thank you to the bus driver.

* Just get off the bus.
* You don't need to say anything....

successfulResults.originalText: calling Ireland Eire...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
What is Eire?

* Eire is another name for Ireland.
* Some people use Eire, but Ireland is more common.
* They both mean the same country....

successfulResults.originalText: The most northerly point in Ireland is in "southern Ireland"....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
The northernmost point in Ireland is in the south.

* Ireland is a big island.
* It has a north and a south.
* The northernmost point is in the south part....

successfulResults.originalText: Using the articles ‚Äûder, die,das‚Äú wrong on obvious words, like saying ‚Äûdie Auto‚Äú instead of ‚Äûdas auto‚Äú. There are some words where even Germans are disputed on wich article to choose but for most word...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When you speak German:

* Use the right word for "car".
* Say "das Auto", not "die Auto".

Some words are tricky. Even Germans disagree on which article to use.
 
But most words have only one correct ...

successfulResults.originalText: I've been learning German the last few years and I reached the conclusion that you learn which article to use on a per word basis. There's no grammar rule that can indicate it....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You learn German:

* You learn which word to use (article) with each word.
* There is no rule to help you decide.
* You learn it one word at a time....

successfulResults.originalText: And then you get Genitiv and Dativ. Fun....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You learn two new words: Genitiv and Dativ.

* Genitiv is a word form.
* Dativ is another word form.

These words are fun to learn!...

successfulResults.originalText: It's really funny, because it's something that just sounds right. For most words there is no rule on what article was commonly agreed upon, so you can't even properly explain it to a foreigner. "Das A...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
It sounds funny because it sounds right. 

* Some words have no rules for articles.
* This makes it hard to explain them.
* "Das Auto" just sounds right....

successfulResults.originalText: It sounds right because we heard it that way all our lives though....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
It sounds right because we heard it that way.

* We heard it many times.
* We heard it since we were young.
* It feels normal to us....

successfulResults.originalText: Bet I‚Äôd never be wrong particularly on ‚Äúdas auto‚Äù, thanks to Volkswagen....
successfulResults.simplifiedText: I'm sure I'm right about "das auto"....

successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You have two countries. 

* Italy (üáÆüáπ)
* Germany (üá©üá™)

You are a citizen in both countries....

successfulResults.originalText: calling it ‚ÄúOz‚Äù or us ‚Äúozzies‚Äù instead of aus or aussie...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You can call Australia:

* Oz
* Ozzies

Do not call it:
 
* Aus
* Aussie...

successfulResults.originalText: Also, using Aussie as a noun instead of an adjective. Like "I'm going to Aussie for a holiday"...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You can say:

* Use Aussie as a noun.
* It's a place, not a description.

Example:

* I'm going to Australia for a holiday.
* Australia is a country, not a feeling.
* You can visit Australia or be fro...

successfulResults.originalText: Or calling Australia the place ‚ÄòAussie‚Äô. Mostly looking at the kiwis for this one...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Let's rewrite it:

We can call Australia 'Aussie'....

successfulResults.originalText: If someone hails a cab like this :...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When you want a taxi:

* Look for a taxi on the street.
* Wave your hand to signal the taxi.
* Go to the taxi and get in....

successfulResults.originalText: That's how you heil a cab....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
To hail a cab:

* Look for a taxi.
* Raise your hand.
* Say "Taxi!"...

successfulResults.originalText: Stand too close to the person in front of you, when queuing for something....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When you're waiting in line:

* Keep some space between you and the person in front.
* Don't stand right next to them....

successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You are known for keeping space from others.

* This is true even before COVID-19.
* You kept a safe distance from others....

successfulResults.simplifiedText:
During COVID, people joked about social distancing.

* There was a rule to stay 2 meters apart.
* People wanted COVID to end so they could go back to their normal distance.

They were joking about goi...

successfulResults.originalText: United States Of America...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
The country is called the United States of America.

It is a place where many people live together....

successfulResults.originalText: we like make long word short...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
We like short words.

* Make words shorter.
* Use simple words.
* Fewer letters are better....

successfulResults.originalText: United States Of America...

successfulResults.originalText: I second this. I work with people from around the world, many who speak fluent English with a standard American accent and it‚Äôs how they use or don‚Äôt use articles that usually tips me off they‚Äôre not ...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When you talk to people from other countries:

* They might speak English very well.
* But they might use words differently.
* They might not use "the" and "a" like Americans do....

successfulResults.originalText: Saying "kiwi" instead of "kiwifruit". You don't eat the bird or the person...well possibly you do, but you don't advertise it....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When you say "kiwi", you mean the fruit.

* You don't mean the bird.
* You don't mean a person from New Zealand (called a Kiwi).
* You mean the green or brown fruit with fuzzy skin....

successfulResults.originalText: Expert-Fisherman-332...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:

* The name is "Expert-Fisherman-332".
* It's a special name for someone.

successfulResults.originalText: They smile too much on the street...

successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Someone was followed by secret police in another country.

* They bought flowers from a shop.

successfulResults.simplifiedText:
It looks like this:

Similar to the three fingers sign....

successfulResults.originalText: Yes, this is a story told by Joe Navarro, an FBI agent who wrote a book about body language with anecdotes about how tiny behavioral differences like this provided clues during Cold War investigations...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When Joe Navarro was an FBI agent, he learned about body language.

He wrote a book about it and shared some stories.

One story is about how people stand when waiting.

* Eastern Europeans stand stra...

successfulResults.originalText: eat a waffle with more toppings than a light sugar coat....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Eat a waffle with lots of toppings.

* Add many toppings to your waffle.
* Use a little bit of sugar on top.
* That's a yummy waffle!...

successfulResults.originalText: Someone calling you "mate" in England in the wrong context....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You are in England.

* You hear someone call you "mate".
* This is not a friend.
* It might be a stranger.

This is not a friendly word in this situation....

successfulResults.originalText: The word "mate" comes in many forms but a non brit will never get it right....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
The word "mate" is tricky.

* It has many different forms.
* People from other countries might not use it correctly.

(Note: "Brit" is short for British person.)...

successfulResults.originalText: Aussies/kiwis/South Africans are an exception to the rule....
successfulResults.simplifiedText: People from Australia, New Zealand, and South Africa are different....

successfulResults.originalText: Not saying sorry for like anything. You bump into someone? Sorry! Someone bumps into you? Sorry! Need to get past? Sorry can I just squeeze through. You're the person in the way? Sorry! Someone says s...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
When you meet someone:

* Say sorry if you bump into them.
* Say sorry if they bump into you.
* Say sorry if you need to get past them.

If you're in the way:

* Say sorry and ask to squeeze through.
...

successfulResults.originalText: This is called a shibboleth - something like this that indicates your belonging to a certain group versus another one....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You are part of a group. 

* A shibboleth is a sign of this.
* It shows you belong to one group, not another....

successfulResults.originalText: Coming over now now, when you were asked to be there just now....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You are expected now.

* Come at this time.
* You were told to be here.
* It is now your turn....

successfulResults.originalText: Sitting beside me on the bus when there is empty seats elsewhere...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
You are on a bus. 

* There are empty seats.
* You sit next to someone.
